title: Description of an Alembic
excerpt: The complete distilling apparatus consists of three parts: the “cucurbit” (Arabic ḳarʿa, Greek βίκος), the still pot containing the liquid to be distilled, which is heated by a flame; the “head” or “cap” (Arabic anbiḳ, Greek ἄμβιξ) which fits over the mouth of the cucurbit to receive the vapors, with an attached downward-sloping “tube” (Greek σωλήν), leading to the “receiver” (Arabic ḳābila, Greek ἄγγος or φιάλη) container.
content:
The complete distilling apparatus consists of three parts: the “cucurbit” (Arabic ḳarʿa, Greek βίκος), the still pot containing the liquid to be distilled, which is heated by a flame; the “head” or “cap” (Arabic anbiḳ, Greek ἄμβιξ) which fits over the mouth of the cucurbit to receive the vapors, with an attached downward-sloping “tube” (Greek σωλήν), leading to the “receiver” (Arabic ḳābila, Greek ἄγγος or φιάλη) container.



Retorts have the “cap” and the “cucurbit” made into one. The anbik is also called the raʾs (head) of the cucurbit. The liquid in the cucurbit is heated or boiled; the vapour rises into the anbik, where it cools by contact with the walls and condenses, running down the spout into the receiver. A modern descendant of the alembic is the pot still, used to produce distilled beverages.

title: History of the Alembic
excerpt: Dioscorides’ ambix (described in his De materia medica) is a helmet-shaped lid for gathering condensed mercury. For Athenaeus (~ 225 C.E.) it is a bottle or flask. For later chemists it denotes various parts of crude distillation devices.
content:
Dioscorides’ ambix (described in his De materia medica) is a helmet-shaped lid for gathering condensed mercury. For Athenaeus (~ 225 C.E.) it is a bottle or flask. For later chemists it denotes various parts of crude distillation devices.



Alembic drawings appear in works of Cleopatra the Alchemist, Synesius, and Zosimos of Panopolis. There were alembics with two (dibikos) and three (tribikos) receivers.[4] According to Zosimos of Panopolis, the alembic was invented by Mary the Jewess.[5]

The anbik is described by Ibn al-Awwam in his Kitab al-Filaha (Book of Agriculture), where he explains how rose-water is distilled. Amongst others, it is mentioned in the Mafatih al-Ulum (Key of Sciences) of Khwarizmi and the Kitab al-Asrar (Book of Secrets) of Al-Razi. Some illustrations occur in the Latin translations of works which are attributed to Geber.[2]

title: Description of a Pot Still
excerpt: A pot still is a type of still used in distilling spirits such as whisky or brandy. Heat is applied directly to the pot containing the wash (for whisky) or wine (for brandy).
content:
A pot still is a type of still used in distilling spirits such as whisky or brandy. Heat is applied directly to the pot containing the wash (for whisky) or wine (for brandy). This is called a batch distillation (as opposed to a continuous distillation).

At standard atmospheric pressure, alcohol boils at 78 °C (172 °F), while water boils at 100 °C (212 °F). During distillation, the vapour contains more alcohol than the liquid. When the vapours are condensed, the resulting liquid contains a higher concentration of alcohol. In the pot still, the alcohol and water vapour combine with esters and flow from the still through the condensing coil. There they condense into the first distillation liquid, the so-called “low wines”. The low wines have a strength of about 25–35% alcohol by volume, and flow into a second still. It is then distilled a second time to produce the colourless spirit, collected at about 70% alcohol by volume. Colour is added through maturation in an oak aging barrel, and develops over time.

The modern pot still is a descendant of the alembic, an earlier distillation device.

title: Dedication
excerpt: Throughout my many lives and until this moment, whatever virtue I have accomplished, including the merit generated by this practice, and all that I will ever attain, this I offer for the welfare of sentient beings.
content:
Dedication

Throughout my many lives and until this moment, whatever virtue I have accomplished, including the merit generated by this practice, and all that I will ever attain, this I offer for the welfare of sentient beings.
May sickness, war, famine, and suffering be decreased for every being,
while their wisdom and compassion increase in this and every future life.
May I clearly perceive all experiences to be as insubstantial as the dream fabric of the night
and instantly awaken to perceive the pure wisdom display in the arising of every phenomenon.
May I quickly attain enlightenment in order to work ceaselessly for the liberation of all sentient beings.

Prayer of Aspiration

Buddhas and bodhisattvas all together:
Whatever kind of motivation you have,
whatever kind of beneficial action,
whatever kind of wishing prayers,
whatever kind of omniscience,
whatever kind of life accomplishment,
whatever kind of benevolent power, and
whatever kind of immense wisdom you have,
then similarly I, who have come in the same way of benefit beings,
pray to attain these qualities.

(Written by Mipham Rinpoche)

The Auspicious Wish

At his very moment, for the peoples and the nations of the earth, may not even the names disease, famine, war and suffering be heard. Rather may their moral conduct, merit, wealth and prosperity increase, and may supreme food fortune and well-being always arise for them.

(Written by Jnama — Jigdral Yeshey Dorge)

title: About
excerpt: The Red Tara Encyclopaedia is a compendium that aims to track all available information on the Red Tara cycle, as revealed by Apong Terton and taught in the West by Chagdud Tulku Rinpoche.
content:
Red Tara Encyclopædia

Tara is the female buddha. The methods we use to attain the enlightened qualities of Tara have been passed down through many perfect lineages of highly realized Tibetan Buddhist practitioners.

This compendium aims to track all available information on the Red Tara cycle (a terma revealed by Apong Terton); and to present it in a structured form. We make aspirations that this could benefit students that want to go deeper in their studies and practice.

Start here:


  Who is Red Tara?
  The history of Red Tara
  How to practice Red Tara meditation?
  Teachers and Dharma Centers


Colophon

The Red Tara Encyclopædia is an open-source project built upon the effort of voluntaries. If you feel that you can help us in any way, feel free to reach us at hello@redtara.org.

Who we are: we are students of Red Tara, revealed by the great Nyingmapa lama Apong Terton, and taught in the West by Chagdud Tulku Rinpoche. This is an independent project with no formal connections to Chagdud Gonpa or any other Dharma center that upholds this lineage.

Authenticity: all content was written accordingly to public teachings and resources of authentic Dharma teachers. You may want to check our article guidelines as well as our vision and motivation for this project. If you believe that any information on this website is incorrect or lack references, please contact us.

Technology: this website runs by the generosity and interdependence of inumerous developers and open-source activists of the past. It’s built with Jekyll and hosted by Github Pages. We use a boilerplate theme called Alembic by David Darnes.

Tipography: the body is composed in Georgia Serif, designed in 1993 by Matthew Carter and Tom Rickner for the Microsoft Corporation. Headings are in Merriweather Serif, a contemporary classic designed by Eben Sorkin. And for monospaced situations we go with Menlo, designed by Jim Lyles for Apple Inc.

License: the Red Tara Encyclopædia is licensed under the GNU General Public License (GPLv3), meaning that, as long as you credit the source, you can do almost anything you want with the content, except distributing closed source versions.
